facts.text: An accident occurred on February 20, 1958, in the Central Bhowra Colliery, Dhanbad, Bihar, resulting in 23 persons losing their lives.

anchor.surface_text: On February 20, 1958, there occurred in the Central Bhowra Colliery, in Dhanbad in Bihar an accident as a result of which 23 persons lost their lives.

facts.text: Inquiry conducted under section 24 of the Mines Act, 1952, into causes and circumstances of the accident, followed by publication of the report.

anchor.surface_text: After an inquiry under. a. 24 of the Mines Act, 1952, into the causes of and the circumstances attending the accident, and the publication of the report of the inquiry

facts.text: Complaint filed by Regional Inspector of Mines, Dhanbad, under direction of Chief Inspector of Mines, before Sub-Divisional Officer, Dhanbad, against appellant for offence under s.74 Mines Act, 1952, for contravention of regulations 107 and 127 of Coal Mines Regulations, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: a companyplains was prepared by the Regional Inspector of Mines,  Dhanbad, under the direction of the Chief Inspector of Mines, Dhanbad, before the Sub-Divisional Officer, Dhanbad, against the appellant for an offence under s. 74 of the Mines Act, 1952, for companytravention of regulations 107 and 127 of the Coal Mines Regulations, 1957.

facts.text: Central Bhowra Colliery owned by M/s. Central Bhowra Colliery Co., Private Limited at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Bhowra Colliery belongs, and belonged at the relevant date to a private companypany, viz., M s. Central Bhowra Colliery Co., Private Limited.

facts.text: Appellant was a shareholder and director of Central Bhowra Colliery Co., Private Limited.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is and was a shareholder and a director of this companypany.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer took cognizance of complaint and issued processes against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: After the Sub- Divisional Officer took companynizance of the companyplaint and issued processes against him

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Art. 226 Constitution to Patna High Court for writ to quash criminal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: , the appellant made an application to the Patna High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution, for the issue of an appropriate writ for quashing the criminal proceedings.

facts.text: Patna High Court summarily dismissed appellant's application on November 21, 1958, in M.J.C. No. 805 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1958, of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. No. 805 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal filed in Supreme Court as Criminal Appeal No. 131 of 1959 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 131 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1958

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Das Gupta, J. on February 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAs GUPTA, J.

facts.text: Appellant contended s.76 Mines Act violates Art.14 as it allows prosecution of any one director/shareholder.

anchor.surface_text: The two main grounds on which the prayer for quashing the proceedings was based were  1  that s. 76 of the Mines Act, 1952, in pursuance of which the appellant, who was number himself the owner of the companyliery companypany, but only one of the directors and shareholders has been prosecuted, is void as it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution

facts.text: Appellant contended Coal Mines Regulations, 1957 invalid for contravention of s.59(3) Mines Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: 2  the Coal Mines Regulations, 1957, are invalid having been framed in companytravention of a. 59 3  of the Mines Act, 1952.

facts.text: No Mining Board constituted under s.12 Mines Act, 1952 when Coal Mines Regulations, 1957 were framed; no reference made.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed before us that when the Regulations were framed, numberBoard as required under s. 12 had been companystituted, and so, necessarily there had been numberreference to any Board as required under s. 59.

facts.text: Respondents claimed Mining Boards under s.10 Mines Act, 1923 were continuing and consulted before framing Coal Mines Regulations, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It has been stated before us however on behalf of the respondents that the Mining Boards companystituted under s. 10 of the Mines Act, 1923, were companytinuing to operate at the time these regulations were framed and that there was-full companysultation with these Mining Boards before these regulations were framed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held word 'any one' in s.76 means 'every one', no violation of Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: This question as regards the interpretation of the word any one in s. 76 was raised in Criminal Appeals Nos. 98 to 106 of 1959  Chief Inspector of Mines etc.   1  and it has been decided there that the word any one should be interpreted there as every one.

facts.text: Supreme Court held provisions of s.59(3) Mines Act, 1952 are mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: For all the reasons given above, we are of opinion that the provisions in s. 59 3  of the Mines Act, 1952, are mandatory.

facts.text: Supreme Court directed criminal proceedings before Sub-Divisional Magistrate to decide if consultation with 1923 Act Mining Boards suffices for s.59(3) compliance.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the proper companyrse, in our opinion, is to direct that the criminal proceedings pending in the companyrt of the sub-divisional magistrate be disposed of by him or any other magistrate to whom the case may be transferred in accordance with law, after deciding the question whether there was companysultation with Mining Boards companystituted under s. 10 of the- Mines Act, 1923, before the regulations were framed and, if so, whether such companysultation amounted to sufficient companypliance with s. 59.

facts.text: Coal Mines Regulations, 1957 framed without reference to Mining Boards under 1952 Act.

holdings.text: the word any one in s. 76 should be interpreted as every one. Thus under s. 76 every one of the shareholders of a private company owning the mine, and every one of the directors of a public company owning the mine is liable to prosecution. No question of violation of Art. 14 therefore arises.

anchor.surface_text: This question as regards the interpretation of the word any one in s. 76 was raised in Criminal Appeals Nos. 98 to 106 of 1959  Chief Inspector of Mines etc.   1  and it has been decided there that the word any one should be interpreted there as every one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent from Criminal Appeals Nos. 98 to 106 of 1959 interpreting 'any one' as 'every one' making provision applicable equally to all directors/shareholders.

holdings.text: the provisions in s. 59(3) of the Mines Act, 1952, are mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: For all the reasons given above, we are of opinion that the provisions in s. 59 3  of the Mines Act, 1952, are mandatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative intent determined from emphatic language, statutory scheme, public benefit of consultation for safety regulations, minimal risk due to s.60 emergency exception, distinguishes Art.320 precedent and Privy Council case.

holdings.text: the proper course is to direct that the criminal proceedings pending in the court of the sub-divisional magistrate be disposed of by him or any other magistrate after deciding the question whether there was consultation with Mining Boards constituted under s. 10 of the Mines Act, 1923, before the regulations were framed and, if so, whether such consultation amounted to sufficient compliance with s. 59.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the proper course, in our opinion, is to direct that the criminal proceedings pending in the court of the sub-divisional magistrate be disposed of by him or any other magistrate to whom the case may be transferred in accordance with law, after deciding the question whether there was consultation with Mining Boards constituted under s. 10 of the- Mines Act, 1923, before the regulations were framed and, if so, whether such consultation amounted to sufficient compliance with s. 59.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient material on facts of consultation with 1923 Act boards and sufficiency thereof; not appropriate for Supreme Court to decide without evidence; remit to trial court.

precedents.citation: Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin

anchor.surface_text: Montreal Street Railway Company v. Nor. mandin

precedents.case_name: Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of a statute relating to performance of public duty are directory if holding them mandatory would work serious general inconvenience or injustice without promoting main object of Legislature
precedents.cited_holding: When the provisions of a statute relate to the performance of a public duty and the case is such that to hold null and void acts done in neglect of this duty would work serious general inconvenience, or injustice to persons who have no control over those entrusted with the duty, and at the same time would not promote the main object of the Legislature, it has been the practice to hold such provisions to be directory only, the neglect of them, though punishable, not affecting the validity of the acts done.

anchor.surface_text: This question as regards the interpretation of the word any one in s. 76 was raised in Criminal Appeals Nos. 98 to 106 of 1959  Chief Inspector of Mines etc.   1  and it has been decided there that the word any one should be interpreted there as every one.
